Name: City-owned vacant property that may be suitable for the development of affordable housing.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to city-owned vacant property that may be suitable for the development of affordable housing

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Amended by Committee
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Committee approved by Roll Call.
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by Roll Call.
This Introduction was Sent to Mayor by Council
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Mayor
This Introduction was Signed Into Law by Mayor
This Introduction was Recved from Mayor by Council

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) to report on the vacant buildings or lots under the jurisdiction of HPD, categorized by the potential to be developed or the feasibility of development those buildings or lots as affordable housing.
Text:
Be it enacted by the Council as follows:

      Section 1. Title 26 of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new chapter 19 to read as follows:
CHAPTER 19
CITY-OWNED VACANT PROPERTY THAT MAY BE SUITABLE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF AFFORDABLE HOUSING

      � 26-1901 City-owned vacant property under the jurisdiction of the department of housing preservation and development that may be suitable for the development of affordable housing. 
      By no later than November 1, 2018, and by November 1 of each year thereafter, the department of housing preservation and development shall, with the cooperation of all other appropriate agencies, report to the mayor and the speaker of the council the following information disaggregated by council district: a report of vacant buildings or lots under the jurisdiction of the department categorized according to the potential development or feasibility status of such buildings or lots as affordable housing.
      � 2. This local law takes effect 180 days it becomes law, except that the commissioner of housing preservation and development may take any actions necessary to its implementation prior to such effective date.
ARP/MPC
LS #2128
12/11/17 4:23pm
